reviewText:
Truly majestic FPS whose epic single player campaign remain in many ways unique to this day.

Unreal is a fantastic, atmospheric journey through beautifully realised alien world, one filled with a sense of mystery and wonder.  It is also a genuine visual and aural feast, and a game that presents level and specific sort of challenge that simply isn't seen anymore.

As is fitting for game's adventurous feel, its levels tend to be huge and exploration-heavy, and often require reading of various clues and careful scrutiny of one's environment in order to proceed. They are always expertly crafted and pleasing to the eye, be they ancient temples and moody ruins with their exquisite architecture, dark spaceship interiors or, especially, Na Pali's unforgettable outdoor locales. Many of Unreal's environments look genuinely beautiful to this day, which is no small feat.

Another expertly crafted element is the soundtrack, which simply cannot be praised enough. Whether the tracks are subtle and evocative, perfectly fitting for game's slower and exploratory sections, or fast and pumping ones that enhance many of game's intense gunfights, they are always excellent and memorable.

Now, game's gunfight are perhaps its most unusual part, one that will make it or break it for most players. Unreal opted for something quite different from the norm: while it has its share of simpler enemies that are focused on simply attacking the player while moving in his general direction (say, some of Na Pali's native fauna), major part of the game is exact opposite from mowing thru hordes of uninteligent meat. Unreal's most dangerous enemies are sparsely placed through its spacious maps, they are agile, hard hitting, constantly in motion and surprisingly intelligent (they will dodge your projectiles, run to cover, fake death etc). Surviving your encounters with these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s requires fast reflexes, awareness of your immediate surroundings and understanding the nuances of game's varied and creative (and highly satisfying, if one allows it to be) weapon arsenal.

This is a must play, and for a particular kind of player that can fully appreciate it, Unreal remains truly one of a kind game: one that was unique back in the day, and one that is even more special today.

Unreal is an FPS from 98' that lives up to it's name, one of the most aesthetically pleasing games to date which  spawned the fantastic Unreal Tournament 99, which is still hands down the master of arena shooters thanks to Unreals flawless engine, extremely talented mappers and great mechanics.. This is one of those games that you NEED to experience before you kick the bucket as it's pretty much the pinnacle of FPS before the massive decline.

The story is pretty simple, you're an inmate who's prisoner transport ship crash landed on an alien planet and you'll need to explore lengthy, non-linear levels to progress, you can learn some of the games interesting lore by reading messages left on the dead bodies of humans, reading diaries and scripture on walls, similar to that in Metroid Prime where you learn all the lore from scanning objects and alien text on walls.

The graphics are incredible, especially being that it was originally released in 98', which was one of the best years for gaming in my opinion. The sound is superb, the weapons sound deadly and powerful. The atmosphere is relentlessly amazing through-out largely thanks to the sound effects, music, scenery, amazing lighting effects and all round amazingly designed levels which see you exploring large layouts, filled with many paths and many hidden secrets while fighting bad-♥♥♥ enemies that fake their death, dodge your attacks and have different behavioural attributes.

The weapons in Unreal are varied and each behaves in a very unique way, my personal favourite being the Flak Cannon which sends shards of flak at your opponents, shredding them to pieces and has an alternate fire of a grenade that explodes on impact.

I honestly envy you if you haven't played this yet, I'd kill to be able to see everything in this game for the first time again, it's an experience made by true masters who took so many obscure factors into consideration that its scary, this is one solid shooter you don't want to miss out on.

Unreal, a game made in 1998. A game that I am sure of many people will remember for it's amazing graphics at the time. Even now in 2015 as I am writing this review, I can still say that Unreal is a great looking game with an amazing plot.

Unreal is a fast paced 1st person shooter with a huge campaign, as well as the possibility to fight in deathmatches, capture the flag and many more gamemodes with bots. The levels in this game can be quite difficult to navigate trough and have many secrets to be revealed, but are all extremely well made. There is a large variety of weapons that you'll aquire troughout the game as well as a large variety of enemies that you'll encounter in Unreal's large amount of levels, giving you the possibility to shoot your way out in every way imaginable.

A thing I should also mention is the difficulty of this game. There are 4 different difficulty settings in this game, easy being the easiest setting and 'unreal' being the hardest. What they did is actually improve the enemies' AI, increase their damage and decrease the amount of ammo, health and upgrades you will find troughout the levels. This is something you'll rarely encounter in nowadays' games where they will just increase the damage you'll take and decrease the damage you deal. Unreal has a great way of spicing up things by making it more difficult in different ways.

Like any other game, it needs music. The music in this game is not just some lousy drums and some silly beeps here and there. No no, there's a lot more to it than just that in Unreal. Each and every track is extremely well made and adds a lot more to just a simple level where you pass a cave or tunnel. As soon as you'll enter a spaceship for example, you'll notice the music will change to a more electronic style which fits really well with the level.

All in all, Unreal is a great fast paced futuristic shooter with a nice variety of weapons, great enemy A.I. and an amazing storyline that I could reccomend to anyone that doesn't care about graphics, but about gameplay instead.

reviewText: Doom may have introduced me to FPS but Unreal was what made me love them. Unreal was the first shooter to make me care about the story experience, I wasn't just here to mow down hordes of aliens, I was a survivor and to continue being a survivor I had to discover this new world's secrets. Told through snippets of detail from crew logs, lore, and environment design, Unreal challenges you to explore and conquer. It leaves you craving explanations and closure while making you dread them just the same, the next corner could have a hidden piece of armor or a Skaarj lurking in the shadows. Draped in atmosphere to accompany the tension Unreal brought its powerhouse visuals to full effect in '98, the advances since make it pale to today's graphical feasts, but it's still easy to get absorbed into the world of Na Pali. Unreal brought a lot more to the table in 1998 with great multiplayer modes, but then it was also far more expensive, it's easy to recommend a single player playthrough for dirt-cheap steam prices. Enjoy.

reviewText:
There is simply no finer game to play as a single player game than UNREAL!
I know it may sound corny, but consider that the game has come out in 1998, and the graphics still look good!
A 'proper' atmosphere, where players with an actual imagination can try out different ways of tackling any baddies, or different ways of reaching 'secret' places.
Probably the most enjoyable aspect of this game would have to be the 'physics' with respect of the character you control to its environment:
the extremely unique double sideways jump, which made the 'space' jump all but absolete, allows you to reach areas with slanted faces in almost a single movement, thus outmaneouvering opponents, especially in multiplayer LAN games, giving freedom of movement a whole new meaning.
The only other game that in my opinion would come close to this kind of control today would have to be: elder scrolls oblivion, another great game, where character control is second to none, especially the jumping ability, something that was unfortunately removed in skyrim.
However, Unreal's real strength (padon the pun, lol) lies with the adventuring and exploration of every nook and crany to find useful items on your journey to escape the planet of the Nali.
Come-on guys, that's a page turner right there, lol.
You're on your own, just crash landed on this UNREAL planet in your prison ship as the only survivor, making your way out of the ship and stepping into a completely alien world of both mysterious wonder and great danger ... now go play the game!

I don't actually play the STEAM version of this game, as I have a fully customized version of it thanks to the support of a still very large UNREAL community, like oldunreal.com, where people still release amazing new player maps, single or multi player ones.
I only bought this game to let the developers know that there are still seriously UNREAL fans out there, and I sincerely wish they would remake the single player game of it again using todays graphics tools and hardware available.
... imagine the eye-candy when playing Nali Castle, Spire or Bluff Eversmoke maps ...
Anyway, before I get too carried away: it's a damn great game, ESPECIALLY if you've never played it!
Get it, then get yourself the high-resolution texture packs, and for heaven's sake, lose yourself in the atmosphere ...
just for the record, I still play this game several times a year for several weeks at a time EVERY YEAR since its release, that's how damn good UNREAL really is!

reviewText: In 1998, Epic Games brought us the original Unreal. Unreal Gold is an Action FPS game created to showcase the original engine of the same name (The Unreal engine). To this day it haunts my dreams with it's large open maps, complex level design, and stunning graphics (for its time). You can't go wrong if you are into older FPS games and this game has always stood out and been unique.

This particular Edition comes with the Return to Na Pali expansion (Which is lower quality imho, but it's still worth a playthrough.)

It features a lot of pretty unique weapons, all designed to show off different aspects of what the engine could do, and they end up being so different that it's actually refreshing. The levels and environments are also varied and interesting. Some of the levels in this game are seriously impressive (I'm looking at you, sunspire). The game is still pretty damn pleasing to look at as well, despite it's lack of polygons and lower res textures, the level design really makes great use of the engine and puts a lot of other 3D shooters of the day to shame.

Where I feel this game really excels above all else, is it's music. It has some of the best video game music I've ever had the pleasure of hearing. Seriously it's an amazing soundtrack, check it out, especially if you like Alexander Brandon.

The game does have a story, but  it's not shoved down your throat. Instead it's told through a universal translator item you obtain near the start of the game, it will pick up various messages from dead bodies, books, computer terminals, and can be read to learn about the world and characters in it. reviewText:
One of the best First Person Shooters ever made (not THE best, though- that's still Deus Ex).

Why?

The gameplay is incredibly solid. The guns are unique and varied, satisfying to use, and balanced, too. The enemies are tough and challenging (it's hard to believe that enemy AI hasn't surpassed a game made in 1998, 16 years later!). The scenery was breathtaking on release, and still doesn't look that bad today. The levels are almost always well designed to reward exploration, and often have multiple ways of getting around. The music is exceptional, and worth a listen to even if you don't own the game. The story does its job well, and the atmosphere is superb.

My few complaints would be that some of the mechanisms for opening doors can be arbitrary and confusing at times, as are the few points where you have to kill a certain amount of enemies to progress.

Overall, you won't be disappointed with this game.

reviewText:
Unreal is a very difficult (provided you play on the later difficulties) and classic FPS from the late 90s. The AI in Unreal and Unreal Tournament 1999 is very advanced, as they become better at dodging rockets and predicting your own movements, which means they'll aim their rockets and other projectiles not directly at you (at least not 100% of the time), but where you're headed, with surprising accuracy. The AI is actually better than most people I've seen play FPSs, and not because their accuracy and HP stats were raised 200% like most games. You, as the player, are also able to use agile dodging moves like the enemies you face. Because of this, and the fact the levels are very large with plenty of secret areas to explore, and a ton of inventory items and weapons to find, Unreal is very fun to play. The graphics are great, and the music is, too. It has most of the same composers as Deus Ex and Unreal Tournament 1999 (obviously).
If you're one of the people who likes a bit of story in their games, Unreal offers a lot of that in the form of a universal translator the player can use to read alien texts and carvings, while also reading the diaries of humans also stranded on the planet you're on.

Music: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1xMp0fZiJaM

Overall, the game is excellent, and for the $10 price tag, you'd be silly not to pick it up.

reviewText:
I like to blame this game for ruining my childhood as it came with the first computer my family purchased and thus sealed my fate as a gamer for years to come.

I remember opening the box and hooking up my Gateway 2000 and installing Unreal. It was one of the earliest forms of awe I can recall when I was navigating through the wreckage of the prison ship and going outside onto an alien planet to confront brutes and skaarj and all the other nasty crap. The story was pretty neat, the graphics, at the time, were awesome. The mechanics were, and still are, pretty solid. This series, including the follow up Unreal Tournament, were easily one of my favorite games to play as a child and experiencing it again as an adult took me down nostalgia avenue and socked me right in the feels.

The action, again, feels smooth and the fights all feel pretty visceral as you blow your enemies to chunks. The environment is as much fun to look at as it is deadly because among being a great FPS it's also got some decent platformer elements combined with some slight puzzle solving areas. Keep in mind none of this is really too difficult but some secret areas can be accessed for more loot or plasma pistol upgrades which really go a long way to making the end game less difficult. As you go through the levels you will find data pads or letters or messages that sort of reveal parts of the story as well as adding some depth to some of the weird scenes you come across. Bodies laying around a room full of guns or some lone crates with chunks of what used to be people beside it tell a story which really adds a lot of immersion to your playthrough.

My only real issue with the game is that some of the graphical settings don't seem to really work but this could just be my machine. Brightness and screen size seem to be constant issues. The only setting that seems to work without issues is 800x600 which is fine, but since I can't really adjust the brigthness level and it seems too dark. Minor gripe for a great classic game.

You, as the player, are also able to use agile dodging moves like the enemies you face. Because of this, and the fact the levels are very large with plenty of secret areas to explore, and a ton of inventory items and weapons to find, Unreal is very fun to play. The graphics are great, and the music is, too. It has most of the same composers as Deus Ex and Unreal Tournament 1999 (obviously).
If you're one of the people who likes a bit of story in their games, Unreal offers a lot of that in the form of a universal translator the player can use to read alien texts and carvings, while also reading the diaries of humans also stranded on the planet you're on.

Overall, the game is excellent, and for the $10 price tag, you'd be silly not to pick it up.

reviewText: Unreal was the game that spawned one of the genre's most popular and enduring series. It blew everyone's mind at the time with how visually impressive it was, featuring some of the most immersive environments ever created. Of course, Halflife came out later the same year and diverted everyone's attention somewhat, but the the original Unreal remains a must play classic. Set in a futuristic techno-gothic universe with a Mayan touch, Unreal is a fairly long game (unlike many of today's) that should provide a satisfying experience in one of the most unforgettable worlds to be created. I hadn't played this in many (about 10) years, and the nostalgia overload as the second map began (stepping out of the prison ship onto the alien world, and THAT music starts) was well worth the reduced price of £2.99 I can tell you! Not all of the level design is as innovative as the outside parts, there are some Doom style dark futuristic corridoor moments to add variety, and the medieval looking parts are vaguely remeniscent of Heretic. There are some instantly memorable level designs here, and a soundtrack that in places is just unforgettable. The enemy AI was very intelligent for its time, the Skaarj and their dodging in particular will cause you to waste plenty of ammo if you don't aim well. Being that this is Unreal Gold, it includes the Return to Na Pali expansion which despite apparently not being as good, is a good addition for extra gameplay. Then of course, you get the original Unreal Botmatch. We all know what this lead to, and indeed it does work like a proto version of UT, featuring several maps (Deck 16 for example) in their original incarnations. A classic that should not be missed.

reviewText:
6.02x10^23 out of 10.
This game features one of the greatest engines ever made, the Unreal Engine.  Without it, countless games are nonexistant.
When this game came out back in '98 I was floored by the scenery.  Escape from the crashed ship and take a minute to look around the world, take in the rich pallet of colors and textures that add so much to the game.  Listen to the score, it's right up there with something by John Williams or Jesper Kyd.  A few years ago they released an Unreal collection that included a cd of the game score, which gets regular play when I'm driving.  I've spent many hours on this alien planet.  It has lots of replay value because of its four difficulty levels.  They don't just make the enemies stronger and your weapons weaker; they make the enemies SMARTER, stronger, and faster, and there's more of them.  There is not much story to the game.  You are a prisoner on the worst prison ship in the galaxy, you have no name, only a number, and the ship crashes on an alien planet.  Your goal is to survive and escape.  No dialog, no cut-scenes, the tutorial is in the manual and if you don't like the default controls you action map them.  Multiplayer is the godfather of Unreal Tournament and its sequels.  This one only has DM, player vs player with or without bots, or player vs bots.  And these bots can get just as brutal as the enemies in single player.
The game has few negative qualities to it.  If you look at it from today's perspective the polygons that make up the world and its inhabitants are obvious and they have no textures when you get up close.  According to an interview with developers, time and budget constraints prevented them from putting better textures on objects when you got up close.  What they did get right is the blood and gore aspect.  Shooting an enemy in the head can result in the head flying off and bouncing around while the body tries to stop the bleeding from the neck.  Explosives can render whole bodies (alive or dead) into bloody chunks that get launched across the room.  Try doing that in Battlefield or Mass Effect.
Bottom line: This game has stood the test of time.  It put time in the camel clutch and made time humble.  If you're stuck on a deserted island this is one of the 3 games to have.

reviewText:
Unreal is an absolute classic and is up there with Quake 2 and Half Life. You play the game as Prisoner 849, who was on a transport ship going to a Moon base prison. However something happens and you awaken with the ship crash landed on a mysterious planet. You blast your way through the game with a whole range of different creative weapons, whilst exploring the planet and trying to figure out what happened to the transport ship by reading varies journals, as well as figuring out a way off the planet.

For its time the graphics were unreal, with amazing looking environments, lighting and textures, which are more well detailed, especially up close. The levels vary from large open fields with a few houses or caves to explore to smaller areas such as a spaceship or a temple. Each area looks unique and it’s easy to distinguish one area from another. The weapons are fun and unique to use such as the bio rifle which shoots green toxic globs and the flak cannon which shoots out shrapnel, which can ricochet off any surface. The enemies vary from slow moving aliens which fire rocket launchers, to fast moving enemies which shoot projectiles at you, almost every enemy in the game shoots a projectile, only a few will use hit scan weapons. The enemy AI is extremely good and are very challenging. You will find yourself dodging left to right to avoid enemy projectiles whilst shooting them down, which can get very intense. From beginning to end this game is a wild ride and is worth a playthrough.

The expansion Return to Na Pali is good but doesn’t live up to the main game. You get a few new weapons, which whilst fun to use aren’t that interesting and some new enemies. The story is told a lot more straight forward, through cut scenes and audio blogs from prisoner 849 if you play as a female. The levels for the most part well designed however the level layout makes no sense, in one level you’re in a base which is located in the middle of a cliff and the next level you’re in the mountains. Worth playing through if you have finished the main game.

Even without the helpful filter of the nostalgia goggles this is a game that has aged exceptionally well; its gunplay is sharp, the AI is smarter than the usual gun-wank, the story is minimalist but compelling and a great example of environmental story-telling in a pre-Fallout 3 FPS. Where the game doesn't hold up is in graphical fidelity; to be expected for a game made in 1998, but for a title that sold itself on the strength of its scenery and set design it's a little disappointing when you realize you can play it on two rocks ducktaped to a piece of glass so long as it was assembled after 2008. I suppose that's nitpicking though, the atmosphere is great and its not hard to see why the scenery was considered some of the best for its time.

The long and short of this review is get it, it's historically important and cheap even if it wasn't a fantastic game. The fact that Epic declined to continue making games for this series and instead focused solely on Unreal Tournament is one of the biggest disappointments in all of gaming.

reviewText:
Not only one of my all-time favorite games now, but I'll even say one of the greatest, most impressive games ever ♥♥♥♥ING made. The original Unreal is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. Lots of awesome original weapons, all with alternate fires, all super fun, and with such meaty sound design. And you gotta love those super deep-voiced grunts when you jump. Lots of fascinating enemies and NPC interactions. Really great lore and worldbuilding from the text logs you can observe, and a real sense of scale and gravitas with the story despite the complete lack of dialogue. No cutscenes, all real-time and ambient, but with sick-♥♥♥ music. Brilliant, brilliant, brilliant map design, with breathtakingly expansive levels to explore.

Aesthetically, everything in the game is just beautiful, even today. Such colorful and lush sci fi landscapes and architecture, and not just the usual everything-is-metal-and-high-tech stuff you often think of when thinking of sci fi settings. It's truly an alien world... And the enemy AI is actually challenging and crazy smart, which is just astounding considering this is a game from 1998 and how lame AI often still is today. The game is really challenging in general, and it is very long.

When I think of a true JOURNEY of a game, I think of this very Unreal right here. No ♥♥♥♥ing Tournament, just plain-♥♥♥ original Unreal 1 right the ♥♥♥♥ here. It is positively... UNREAL, the places you'll go in this game. The very definition of an adventure. People always going on about how great Half-life is, but I honestly feel this game might be a notch or two more amazing than Half-life, for the same sorts of reasons Half-life 1 was/is awesome. And I do ♥♥♥♥ing LOVE Half-life. This game... This game gave me feelings, guys. Real ♥♥♥♥ing feelings. I was truly in awe. This game should be recognized more, and it has my 100% recommendation, especially considering the price.


The expansion, Return to Na Pali gives a bunch more levels for even more Unreal goodness and continues the story directly where Unreal 1 left off, but the player character is suddenly given a voice, and I think that goes against what the original Unreal was about. He'll (you'll) talk in between levels in some dumb kinda unncessary monologue about what just happened and what's going to happen next. So Return to Na Pali is the same fun as Unreal 1, but with some mediocre new narrative style. So even including Return to Na Pali and Unreal 2 (which goes even further into the voiced characters, try-hard hamfisted story ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t territory, and is really quite a different kind of game altogether), there truly hasn't been another game quite like Unreal since Unreal came out all these years ago, and while the Unreal Tournament games aren't bad, I think it's a damn shame Epic (Mega)Games never made another game as incredible in the way Unreal was. Here's hoping for a really good current-gen remake of some sort; this singleplayer Unreal truly deserves another chance in the spotlight. Or perhaps a whole new Unreal game altogether, if they can nail it like this one did, and take away from the stains of Return to Na Pali and Unreal 2. It is one of the most amazing experiences I've ever played, and I wish more people could understand what I'm talking about by playing the game for themselves. So go do that, reader! It's totally worth it, trust me on this one. That so few people talk about this game just astounds me. And there's also multiplayer, yes.

reviewText: Unreal Gold is a sci-fi fps made in 1998 by Epic Games, you play as an escaped prisoner on an alien planet, there are over 47 maps on single player and extra maps in the Return to Na Pali expansion pack, which comes bundled with this version of the game. When you first buy the game, make sure you adjust the settings to your preferances and optimize the game to run best on your device, I recommend changing the graphical/audio settings, character models, controlls and interface settings before you start playing. There is also multiplayer and bot matches, which host about 20 additional maps, you can set up a match with your friends or if you don't want the fuss just start a bot match and practice, get a hang of the maps and weapons to learn while you progress.

Unreal Gold is a slightly older version of Unreal Tournament with 2 single player campaigns and regular bot deathmatch.

It is not the first 3D FPS but it is the most important one because of its ground braking physics engine . Unreal is the point where modern FPS was born and the engine itself became groundwork for modern game developing tools .

These days we take much of what Unreal introduced for granted as a base line for what FPS should be. However back then it was ambitious to create a fluid FPS game in 3D . There isn't much I can say about gameplay as the game comes down to walking,shooting and pressing buttons .

I will say that there are some jump scares with predators XD This is the FPS that introduced a lot of enviromental 3D events . Sometimes lights will go off and some alien will brake through wall so he can kill you (these days it happens all the time right)

If a game like this came out today (and they have) I would not like it . However in respect to timeframe it is made Unreal was THE FPS  . Right now game is $10 on sale and I would not recommend it for someone new to the series just because it is a generic game in 2015 and probably not worth it .

Perhaps this game isn't very good for new audience but if you are interested in the roots of FPS genre give it a try on sale .It has a charm that never fades away .
